title: 1 Samuel Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 2.

questions.question: Who prayed and said, 'My heart rejoiceth in the LORD' in 1 Samuel Chapter 2?
options: Hannah
Samuel
Eli
Elkanah
questions.correctAnswer: Hannah
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:1 states that Hannah prayed and said these words.

questions.question: What does Hannah say is exalted in the LORD in 1 Samuel 2:1?
options: Her horn
Her crown
Her spirit
Her heart
questions.correctAnswer: Her horn
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:1 says, 'mine horn is exalted in the LORD.'

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 2:2, what is said about the LORD?
options: There is none holy as the LORD
The LORD is a consuming fire
The LORD is a man of war
The LORD is a mighty king
questions.correctAnswer: There is none holy as the LORD
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:2 states, 'There is none holy as the LORD.'

questions.question: True or False: 1 Samuel 2:3 instructs not to let arrogancy come out of your mouth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:3 says, 'let not arrogancy come out of your mouth.'

questions.question: What happens to the bows of the mighty men according to 1 Samuel 2:4?
options: They are broken
They are strengthened
They are sharpened
They are lifted up
questions.correctAnswer: They are broken
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:4 states, 'The bows of the mighty men are broken.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The LORD killeth, and maketh ______: he bringeth down to the grave, and bringeth up.'
options: alive
peace
war
rich
questions.correctAnswer: alive
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:6 says, 'The LORD killeth, and maketh alive.'

questions.question: Who did Samuel minister before according to 1 Samuel 2:11?
options: Eli the priest
Hannah
Elkanah
Phinehas
questions.correctAnswer: Eli the priest
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:11 states that Samuel ministered before Eli the priest.

questions.question: True or False: The sons of Eli were righteous men who knew the LORD well.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:12 says the sons of Eli were sons of Belial and knew not the LORD.

questions.question: What did the priest's servant use to take the meat from the sacrifices in 1 Samuel 2:13?
options: A fleshhook of three teeth
A golden spoon
A silver bowl
A wooden ladle
questions.correctAnswer: A fleshhook of three teeth
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:13 describes the use of a fleshhook of three teeth.

questions.question: What did the priests' sons demand from those offering sacrifices before the fat was burned according to 1 Samuel 2:15?
options: Flesh to roast
Silver coins
Grain offerings
Water to drink
questions.correctAnswer: Flesh to roast
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:15 states that the priest's servant demanded flesh to roast.

questions.question: True or False: Samuel ministered before the LORD wearing a linen ephod as a child.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:18 says Samuel ministered before the LORD girded with a linen ephod.

questions.question: What did Eli bless Elkanah and his wife with in 1 Samuel 2:20?
options: The LORD give thee seed of this woman
Wealth and long life
Peace and prosperity
Victory over enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD give thee seed of this woman
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:20 records Eli blessing Elkanah and his wife with seed from the woman for the loan lent to the LORD.

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 2:21, how many children did Hannah bear after the LORD visited her?
options: Three sons and two daughters
One son and one daughter
Five sons
Two sons and three daughters
questions.correctAnswer: Three sons and two daughters
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:21 states Hannah bore three sons and two daughters.

questions.question: What did Eli hear about his sons in 1 Samuel 2:22?
options: They lay with the women that assembled at the tabernacle
They faithfully served the LORD
They cared for the widows and orphans
They taught the people the law
questions.correctAnswer: They lay with the women that assembled at the tabernacle
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:22 says Eli heard how his sons lay with the women assembled at the tabernacle door.

questions.question: What will happen to the house of Eli according to the man of God’s prophecy in 1 Samuel 2:34?
options: Hophni and Phinehas will die on the same day
The house will be blessed forever
The house will rule Israel
The house will be rich and powerful
questions.correctAnswer: Hophni and Phinehas will die on the same day
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:34 states that both sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, would die on the same day.

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 1 Samuel 2, what biblical truth would you share about God's control over life circumstances?
options: God kills and makes alive; He brings down to the grave and raises up (1 Samuel 2:6).
God always prevents trials from happening (1 Samuel 2:4).
God only blesses those who never struggle (1 Samuel 2:5).
God ignores human suffering (1 Samuel 2:7).
questions.correctAnswer: God kills and makes alive; He brings down to the grave and raises up (1 Samuel 2:6).
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:6 teaches that the LORD controls life and death, bringing down to the grave and raising up, highlighting His sovereignty in trials. This is supported by verses 7 and 8 which show God’s power to lift up and bring low.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 2 instruct us about humility and pride in our speech and actions?
options: Do not speak arrogantly, for the LORD is a God of knowledge who weighs actions (1 Samuel 2:3).
Pride is a sign of God’s blessing and favor (1 Samuel 2:4).
Boast about yourself to show your strength (1 Samuel 2:1).
Ignore how God judges actions and focus on appearances (1 Samuel 2:2).
questions.correctAnswer: Do not speak arrogantly, for the LORD is a God of knowledge who weighs actions (1 Samuel 2:3).
questions.explanation: Verse 3 warns against arrogant speech because God knows all and weighs our actions, emphasizing humility. This aligns with the principle of fearing God and having a humble heart found in verses 2 and 9.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 2 teach about God’s care for the poor and the humble?
options: God raises the poor out of the dust and lifts the beggar to princely positions (1 Samuel 2:8).
God ignores the poor and only blesses the wealthy (1 Samuel 2:7).
The poor must earn their way without God’s help (1 Samuel 2:5).
Poverty is always a punishment from God (1 Samuel 2:6).
questions.correctAnswer: God raises the poor out of the dust and lifts the beggar to princely positions (1 Samuel 2:8).
questions.explanation: Verse 8 clearly shows God’s power to lift the poor and humble to positions of honor, reminding believers to trust God’s providence and care. This is consistent with the themes in verses 7 and 9 about God’s sovereign uplifting.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness toward enemies. What can you share from Hannah’s prayer about rejoicing and trusting in God’s salvation?
options: Rejoice in the LORD’s salvation, as Hannah’s heart was exalted and her mouth enlarged over her enemies (1 Samuel 2:1).
Harbor bitterness and seek revenge (1 Samuel 2:4).
Ignore God’s salvation and depend on your own strength (1 Samuel 2:7).
Avoid praying about enemies (1 Samuel 2:3).
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoice in the LORD’s salvation, as Hannah’s heart was exalted and her mouth enlarged over her enemies (1 Samuel 2:1).
questions.explanation: Hannah’s prayer in verse 1 encourages believers to rejoice in God’s salvation even in the face of enemies, modeling a heart of trust and praise. This contrasts with arrogance and bitterness warned against in verse 3.

questions.question: Based on 1 Samuel 2, what biblical teaching can be shared about the importance of integrity and honesty in service to God?
options: The sons of Eli acted wickedly and dishonestly, causing sin before the LORD (1 Samuel 2:12, 17).
Cheating and taking advantage of others is acceptable in God’s house (1 Samuel 2:14).
Dishonest priests are praised by God (1 Samuel 2:15).
God ignores how we serve Him (1 Samuel 2:16).
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Eli acted wickedly and dishonestly, causing sin before the LORD (1 Samuel 2:12, 17).
questions.explanation: Verses 12 and 17 describe the corrupt actions of Eli’s sons, highlighting that dishonesty and sin in serving God are serious offenses. This teaches believers to serve with integrity and reverence.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 2 model a pattern of faithful service and devotion in family life?
options: Samuel ministered before the LORD as a child, supported by his mother’s care and yearly offerings (1 Samuel 2:18-19).
Children should not be involved in spiritual service (1 Samuel 2:22).
Parents must ignore their children’s spiritual growth (1 Samuel 2:20).
Family life and spiritual service are unrelated (1 Samuel 2:21).
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel ministered before the LORD as a child, supported by his mother’s care and yearly offerings (1 Samuel 2:18-19).
questions.explanation: Verses 18 and 19 show Samuel’s faithful service from childhood with his mother’s nurturing support, illustrating the importance of spiritual training and family involvement in God’s work.

questions.question: What principle about God’s justice and judgment can be learned from Eli’s rebuke of his sons in 1 Samuel 2?
options: Sin against the LORD is more serious and cannot be overlooked by human judgment (1 Samuel 2:24-25).
All sins are equal and require no special attention (1 Samuel 2:23).
Judges should not confront sin within their own families (1 Samuel 2:22).
God does not punish sin in leaders (1 Samuel 2:26).
questions.correctAnswer: Sin against the LORD is more serious and cannot be overlooked by human judgment (1 Samuel 2:24-25).
questions.explanation: Eli’s words in verses 24 and 25 emphasize that sin against God is especially grievous and cannot be excused, teaching believers to take holiness seriously.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Samuel 2, God will honor those who honor Him and lightly esteem those who despise Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 30 clearly states that God honors those who honor Him and lightly esteems those who despise Him, encouraging believers to live in reverence and obedience.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Samuel 2 shows that God’s blessings and riches are permanent and unchanging regardless of one’s heart condition.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 30 teach that God is the one who makes rich or poor and honors or lightly esteems according to one’s heart and actions, indicating blessings depend on relationship with God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Hannah’s prayer, she says, 'My heart rejoiceth in the _______, mine horn is exalted in the LORD.'
options: LORD
enemy
world
king
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 1 states Hannah’s heart rejoices in the LORD, showing her trust and praise directed to God alone.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 2 teach about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s timing?
options: Hannah was barren but God visited her and gave her children in His time (1 Samuel 2:5, 21).
God always blesses instantly without waiting (1 Samuel 2:10).
Trials mean God has abandoned you (1 Samuel 2:6).
You should not hope for change in difficult circumstances (1 Samuel 2:4).
questions.correctAnswer: Hannah was barren but God visited her and gave her children in His time (1 Samuel 2:5, 21).
questions.explanation: Verses 5 and 21 highlight Hannah’s barrenness and God’s eventual blessing, teaching believers to trust God’s perfect timing and faithfulness.

questions.question: What warning does 1 Samuel 2 give about abusing spiritual authority and greed in church life?
options: Eli’s sons abused their priestly office by taking offerings unlawfully and causing people to abhor the LORD’s offering (1 Samuel 2:14-17).
Spiritual leaders can take as much as they want without consequence (1 Samuel 2:13).
Greed in church leadership is acceptable if it increases wealth (1 Samuel 2:16).
People should ignore corrupt leaders and not confront sin (1 Samuel 2:22).
questions.correctAnswer: Eli’s sons abused their priestly office by taking offerings unlawfully and causing people to abhor the LORD’s offering (1 Samuel 2:14-17).
questions.explanation: These verses describe the corrupt practices of Eli’s sons, warning that greed and abuse in spiritual leadership lead to God’s judgment and loss of respect for God’s offerings.

questions.question: Based on 1 Samuel 2, how should believers approach prayer and personal devotion?
options: Like Hannah, pray with a rejoicing heart, exalting God’s salvation and power (1 Samuel 2:1-2).
Pray only when in trouble and complain to God (1 Samuel 2:3).
Avoid praising God for His holiness (1 Samuel 2:2).
Make your prayers boastful and focused on your own strength (1 Samuel 2:1).
questions.correctAnswer: Like Hannah, pray with a rejoicing heart, exalting God’s salvation and power (1 Samuel 2:1-2).
questions.explanation: Hannah’s prayer in verses 1 and 2 models joyful, humble worship that praises God’s holiness and saving power, encouraging believers to cultivate heartfelt devotion.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 2 teach about God raising up faithful servants for His purposes?
options: God will raise up a faithful priest who will do according to His heart and walk before His anointed forever (1 Samuel 2:35).
God only works through corrupt leaders (1 Samuel 2:12).
Faithful servants are not important in God’s plan (1 Samuel 2:36).
God abandons His promises to raise leaders (1 Samuel 2:31).
questions.correctAnswer: God will raise up a faithful priest who will do according to His heart and walk before His anointed forever (1 Samuel 2:35).
questions.explanation: Verse 35 promises that God will raise a faithful servant aligned with His will, assuring believers of God’s ongoing faithful leadership.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 2 instruct believers about contentment and gratitude in life’s circumstances?
options: Those who are full may become servants for bread, and the hungry cease; the barren bear children, and the many become feeble (1 Samuel 2:5).
Always strive for more and never be satisfied (1 Samuel 2:7).
Gratitude is not important in spiritual life (1 Samuel 2:1).
God only blesses those who never struggle (1 Samuel 2:6).
questions.correctAnswer: Those who are full may become servants for bread, and the hungry cease; the barren bear children, and the many become feeble (1 Samuel 2:5).
questions.explanation: Verse 5 reminds believers that circumstances change and God controls life’s seasons, encouraging contentment and gratitude regardless of condition.

questions.question: What lesson about family discipline and correction is found in Eli’s response to his sons’ sin in 1 Samuel 2?
options: Eli rebuked his sons for their evil deeds and warned them not to make the LORD’s people transgress (1 Samuel 2:22-24).
Eli ignored their sin completely (1 Samuel 2:26).
Parents should support any behavior of their children (1 Samuel 2:20).
Eli praised his sons’ actions before the people (1 Samuel 2:18).
questions.correctAnswer: Eli rebuked his sons for their evil deeds and warned them not to make the LORD’s people transgress (1 Samuel 2:22-24).
questions.explanation: These verses show Eli’s attempt to correct his sons, teaching the importance of parental responsibility in spiritual discipline and warning against causing others to sin.

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 2.

questions.question: Hannah's prayer in 1 Samuel 2:1 demonstrates which literary device that emphasizes her joy and God's salvation?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Allegory
Metaphor
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Hannah's prayer employs parallelism as seen in the repetition of exaltation and rejoicing in the LORD, typical of Hebrew poetry (1 Samuel 2:1).

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 2:2, the phrase 'there is none beside thee' reflects a theological assertion about God found also in which Old Testament book?
options: Deuteronomy
Isaiah
Exodus
Psalms
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah
questions.explanation: The exclusivity of God in 1 Samuel 2:2 parallels Isaiah's frequent assertion of God's uniqueness, such as in Isaiah 45:5.

questions.question: What does the Hebrew term translated as 'horn' in 1 Samuel 2:1 symbolize in ancient Near Eastern culture?
options: Strength and power
Wealth and prosperity
Wisdom and knowledge
Peace and tranquility
questions.correctAnswer: Strength and power
questions.explanation: The 'horn' metaphorically represents strength and power, common in ancient Near Eastern symbolism and biblical texts (1 Samuel 2:1).

questions.question: The warning against arrogance in 1 Samuel 2:3 reflects which broader biblical theme about human pride?
options: God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble
Pride is the root of all sin
Pride leads to immediate destruction
Pride is a sign of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:3 warns against arrogance, aligning with Proverbs 3:34 and James 4:6 emphasizing God's opposition to the proud.

questions.question: The imagery of bows broken and the mighty made weak in 1 Samuel 2:4 is an example of what type of biblical poetic device?
options: Metaphor
Simile
Hyperbole
Personification
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: The broken bows metaphorically describe the reversal of fortune by divine intervention (1 Samuel 2:4).

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 2:5 use irony to depict social reversal?
options: The barren woman bears seven children while the fruitful woman becomes weak
The rich become poor and the poor become rich
The mighty fall and the weak rise
Enemies rejoice instead of being defeated
questions.correctAnswer: The barren woman bears seven children while the fruitful woman becomes weak
questions.explanation: The verse uses irony to illustrate God's power to overturn natural expectations and social norms (1 Samuel 2:5).

questions.question: Which theological concept is expressed by the statement 'The LORD killeth, and maketh alive' in 1 Samuel 2:6?
options: Sovereignty over life and death
Resurrection after death
Judgment of nations
Punishment for sin
questions.correctAnswer: Sovereignty over life and death
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes God's absolute control over life and death, a recurring biblical theme (1 Samuel 2:6).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Samuel 2:7, God is portrayed as the one who determines social status by making poor or rich and lifting up or bringing low.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states God's power over social elevation and humbling (1 Samuel 2:7).

questions.question: What is the significance of the imagery of 'pillars of the earth' in 1 Samuel 2:8 within the ancient Near Eastern worldview?
options: It reflects the belief in a stable, divinely supported cosmos
It symbolizes the strength of human rulers
It indicates the foundation of a temple
It refers to the mountains surrounding Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the belief in a stable, divinely supported cosmos
questions.explanation: The 'pillars of the earth' phrase symbolizes God's sustaining power over the world, consistent with ANE cosmology (1 Samuel 2:8).

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 2:10, 'the horn of his anointed' is a Messianic reference. Which New Testament passage echoes this imagery?
options: Luke 1:32
John 1:29
Acts 2:36
Revelation 19:16
questions.correctAnswer: Luke 1:32
questions.explanation: Luke 1:32 refers to Jesus as the Son of the Most High, whose kingdom is symbolized by an exalted horn, linking messianic expectations (1 Samuel 2:10).

questions.question: How does the behavior of Eli’s sons described in 1 Samuel 2:12-17 illustrate a theme of corruption in religious leadership?
options: They abused their priestly privileges for personal gain
They faithfully served the LORD with humility
They led the people in repentance
They built new altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They abused their priestly privileges for personal gain
questions.explanation: The sons of Eli exploited sacrifices for selfish benefit, showing corrupt leadership (1 Samuel 2:12-17).

questions.question: What is the significance of Samuel ministering 'girded with a linen ephod' as described in 1 Samuel 2:18?
options: It indicates his role as a priestly servant
It signifies royal authority
It shows he was a warrior
It means he was a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates his role as a priestly servant
questions.explanation: The linen ephod was a priestly garment, signifying Samuel’s service in the sanctuary (1 Samuel 2:18).

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 2:21, how did God respond to Hannah’s faithfulness?
options: He blessed her with children
He destroyed her enemies
He made her a prophetess
He granted her riches
questions.correctAnswer: He blessed her with children
questions.explanation: God visited Hannah and gave her three sons and two daughters as a blessing (1 Samuel 2:21).

questions.question: The prophetic message to Eli in 1 Samuel 2:27-36 includes which of the following elements?
options: Judgment on Eli’s house due to sons’ sins
Promise of eternal priesthood for Eli’s descendants
Command to rebuild the tabernacle
Call to lead Israel into battle
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment on Eli’s house due to sons’ sins
questions.explanation: The man of God pronounces judgement on Eli’s house because of the sons’ corruption and dishonoring of God (1 Samuel 2:27-36).

questions.question: How does the prophecy about a 'faithful priest' raised up in 1 Samuel 2:35 foreshadow New Testament priesthood?
options: It anticipates Christ as the ultimate faithful priest
It refers to a future Levitical priest only
It predicts the rebuilding of the temple
It points to the coming of John the Baptist
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates Christ as the ultimate faithful priest
questions.explanation: This prophecy is often understood as foreshadowing Jesus Christ’s perfect priesthood (Hebrews 7:26–28) (1 Samuel 2:35).

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What theological truth about God is expressed in Hannah's prayer in 1 Samuel 2:2?
options: There is none holy like the LORD, and no rock like our God
God is distant and unknowable
God is like other gods of the nations
God depends on human strength for victory
questions.correctAnswer: There is none holy like the LORD, and no rock like our God
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 2:2 affirms God's unique holiness and immovability as our rock. This aligns with Exodus 15:11, Isaiah 43:10-11, Deuteronomy 32:4, and Psalm 18:2, all emphasizing God's holiness and unchanging nature.

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 2:3, why should people refrain from arrogance?
options: Because the LORD is a God of knowledge and weighs actions
Because pride is socially unacceptable
Because arrogance brings material loss
Because humility is a cultural norm
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is a God of knowledge and weighs actions
questions.explanation: Verse 3 teaches that arrogance is futile because God knows all and judges actions justly. Proverbs 16:18, James 4:6, and 1 Peter 5:5 similarly warn against pride and affirm God's omniscient judgment.

questions.question: What characteristic of God's sovereign power is demonstrated in 1 Samuel 2:6-7?
options: God controls life and death, poverty and riches, humility and exaltation
God only blesses the righteous
God is limited by human decisions
God cannot change human conditions
questions.correctAnswer: God controls life and death, poverty and riches, humility and exaltation
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 reveal God's absolute sovereignty over all life conditions, consistent with Job 1:21, Deuteronomy 8:18, and James 1:17, which show God as the ultimate giver and taker of life and blessings.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 2:8 describe God's care for the lowly and needy?
options: God raises the poor from dust and sets the needy among princes
God ignores the poor and favors the rich
God only blesses the religious leaders
God punishes the poor for their condition
questions.correctAnswer: God raises the poor from dust and sets the needy among princes
questions.explanation: Verse 8 emphasizes God's uplifting of the humble, consistent with Psalm 113:7-8, Luke 1:52, James 2:5, and Matthew 5:3, which affirm God's preferential care for the poor and humble.

questions.question: What eschatological theme is found in 1 Samuel 2:10 regarding the LORD and His anointed king?
options: The LORD will judge the earth and give strength to His anointed king
The LORD will abandon His people in the last days
The LORD's power is limited to Israel only
The LORD's anointed king will fail against enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will judge the earth and give strength to His anointed king
questions.explanation: Verse 10 prophesies God's universal judgment and empowering of His anointed, a messianic theme echoed in Psalm 2:6-9, Daniel 7:13-14, Isaiah 9:6-7, and Acts 2:30-31 about the coming Messiah's reign.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 2:12 reveal about the sons of Eli and their relationship with God?
options: They were sons of Belial and did not know the LORD
They were faithful priests serving God
They were prophets inspired by God
They were humble servants of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They were sons of Belial and did not know the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 12 depicts Eli's sons as wicked and ignorant of God, paralleling similar condemnations in Ezekiel 22:26, Jeremiah 23:11, and 2 Chronicles 26:16-21 about corrupt religious leaders.

questions.question: What sinful behavior is described in 1 Samuel 2:13-16 concerning the priestly servants?
options: They took the best parts of sacrifices by force before they were properly offered
They faithfully offered sacrifices on behalf of the people
They refused to accept gifts from the people
They only ate after the sacrifices were completed
questions.correctAnswer: They took the best parts of sacrifices by force before they were properly offered
questions.explanation: Verses 13-16 expose the greed and abuse by priestly servants who seized sacrificial portions prematurely. This corruption is condemned similarly in Malachi 1:8, Amos 5:21-24, and Micah 3:11.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 2:17 describe the consequence of the sons of Eli's sinfulness?
options: The sin was very great, causing people to abhor the LORD's offering
Their sin was overlooked because of their priestly status
Their sin brought prosperity to Israel
Their sin was only a private matter
questions.correctAnswer: The sin was very great, causing people to abhor the LORD's offering
questions.explanation: Verse 17 highlights that the sons' sin caused a rejection of God's offerings, reflecting the serious consequences of unholy leadership as in Isaiah 1:11-17, Hebrews 10:29, and 1 Corinthians 11:27-29.

questions.question: What role is Samuel described as fulfilling in 1 Samuel 2:18?
options: Samuel ministered before the LORD as a child, wearing a linen ephod
Samuel was rebellious against the LORD
Samuel was a warrior leading Israel
Samuel served as a priest's servant with corrupt practices
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel ministered before the LORD as a child, wearing a linen ephod
questions.explanation: Verse 18 shows Samuel's faithful service to God from childhood, symbolized by the ephod, an important priestly garment. This is consistent with Luke 2:52, Jeremiah 1:5, and 1 Timothy 4:12 emphasizing godly growth and service.

questions.question: What promise does Eli give to Elkanah and Hannah in 1 Samuel 2:20?
options: The LORD will give them children as a loan to the LORD
They will never have children
They will become rulers over Israel
They will be cursed for their sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will give them children as a loan to the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 20 records Eli blessing the couple with a promise of children given by God as a sacred loan, similar to Hannah’s vow in 1 Samuel 1:11, and God's gifts of children in Psalm 127:3 and Genesis 30:22-24.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 2:25 teach about sin against the LORD compared to sin against other people?
options: Sin against the LORD has no intercessor, unlike sin against others
Sin against the LORD is less serious
Sin against others is never judged
There is always forgiveness without repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Sin against the LORD has no intercessor, unlike sin against others
questions.explanation: Verse 25 emphasizes the gravity of sin against God, highlighting the lack of intercession. This aligns with Numbers 35:31, Hebrews 10:26-31, and Isaiah 59:1-2, underscoring divine justice and the need for repentance.

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 2:26, how did Samuel grow in relation to God and men?
options: Samuel grew in favor both with the LORD and with men
Samuel was rejected by the people but favored by God
Samuel grew only in physical strength
Samuel was isolated and unknown
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel grew in favor both with the LORD and with men
questions.explanation: Verse 26 reveals Samuel’s spiritual and social maturity, favored by God and people, consistent with Luke 2:52 and Proverbs 3:3-4, depicting ideal godly growth and reputation.

questions.question: What was the message from the man of God to Eli in 1 Samuel 2:27-30 regarding his house and priesthood?
options: God would cut off Eli’s house for dishonoring Him and blessing his sons above God
God would bless Eli’s house forever without condition
God was indifferent to the priestly corruption
Eli's sons would succeed as high priests
questions.correctAnswer: God would cut off Eli’s house for dishonoring Him and blessing his sons above God
questions.explanation: These verses pronounce judgment on Eli’s family for corrupting the priesthood, a theme echoed in Jeremiah 22:30, Ezekiel 44:23, and Hebrews 7:11-19 concerning faithful priestly service and divine judgment.

questions.question: What sign of judgment against Eli’s sons is given in 1 Samuel 2:34?
options: Both sons would die on the same day
They would be exiled from Israel
They would repent and be forgiven
They would become kings
questions.correctAnswer: Both sons would die on the same day
questions.explanation: Verse 34 specifies the imminent death of Hophni and Phinehas as a sign of judgment, consistent with the theme of divine justice in Ezekiel 21:25-27 and the fulfillment of God's word in 1 Samuel 4:11.

questions.question: Who does God promise to raise up as a faithful priest in 1 Samuel 2:35 and what is his role?
options: A faithful priest who will do according to God's heart and walk before His anointed forever
A corrupt priest who will bring destruction
A king who will overthrow the priesthood
A prophet who will replace the priests
questions.correctAnswer: A faithful priest who will do according to God's heart and walk before His anointed forever
questions.explanation: Verse 35 promises the raising of a faithful priest aligned with God's will, prefiguring Christ as the eternal High Priest in Hebrews 7:23-28, Psalm 110:4, and Zechariah 6:13.

questions.question: What future humility and dependence is predicted for Eli’s house in 1 Samuel 2:36?
options: They will come and crouch to the faithful priest for a piece of silver and bread
They will rule Israel with great power
They will be honored above all priests
They will be independent and wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: They will come and crouch to the faithful priest for a piece of silver and bread
questions.explanation: Verse 36 foretells the humiliation and dependence of Eli’s descendants on the faithful priest, illustrating judgment and reversal of fortunes similar to Jonah 2:8 and Micah 3:11.
